Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigating how Conical Intersection Topography Drives Photochemistry using High-Sensitivity Femtosecond Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Daniel Turner of New York University and his research group conducts experimental studies aimed at understanding how certain coordinated motions of the nuclei and electrons in molecules determine the outcomes of photochemical reactions. The research improves the fundamental understanding of several light-driven processes, including mechanisms of solar energy conversion. The activities enhance secondary education, enable mentoring by retired scientists, promote science to the public, and produce scientists equipped to apply technical and quantitative skills in research, industry, and education.

This project focuses on the detection of conical intersections and extraction of topographic information from femtosecond spectroscopy experiments. By clarifying the role of conical intersections in condensed-phase photochemistry, the proposed experimental studies not only resolve questions about conical intersection topography that have been postulated by computational work, but also guide and motivate future theoretical efforts. The molecules to be measured, oxazines and phytochromes, serve as model systems for studying how conical intersections mediate nonradiative decay and drive photo-isomerization reactions, respectively. The broader impacts include training young researchers for scientific careers, disseminating science to the general public through a partnership with The Huffington Post, creating a website that captures the expertise of retired scientists to fill in the gaps created by generational turnover of research trends, and, through a partnership with high school teachers, developing feasible science labs for underprivileged schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the study of a class of chemical reactions that are initiated by light and lead to molecular transformations or signal transduction. The light causes these molecular-level changes through nonadiabatic processes. The dynamics of nonadiabatic processes occur on femtosecond (fs) timescales; 1 fs is a millionth of a billionth of a second. Most molecules are too small to be seen with light microscopes on these speeds, and therefore we used laser spectroscopy techniques. A laser spectrometer is a custom laboratory instrument that uses light to infer information by examining in great detail how a molecule absorbs light. Because the nonadiabatic dynamics occur so quickly, we used laser pulses having durations as short as 5 fs, which are some of the fastest optical pulses ever created and used for scientific measurements.  Spectroscopic signatures of nonadiabatic transformations are not only fast, but also weak and elusive, and therefore we developed new methods to increase the sensitivity of the spectrometers that we built.  We published several papers about the development of these new techniques and methods.  During the grant period, we published a series of papers reporting on nonadiabatic dynamics in small molecules, in transition-metal compounds having large spin-orbit coupling, and in pigment—protein complexes called phytochromes that plants use for shade avoidance.  This research produced new insights into the transduction mechanisms for converting light into photoactivity. This information will inform the engineering of optogenetic actuators for potential application in neurological diseases.  In a related - albeit distinct - effort, we also studied singlet fission in a crystal of the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon, rubrene. Single fission is a nonadiabatic process that can, in principle, generate two electrons from a single photon, but it occurs in only a few known materials.  Next-generation photovoltaics would benefit greatly from the incorporation of singlet-fission materials.  We also made a key serendipitous discovery about the subtle signatures of resonance energy transfer in femtosecond laser spectroscopy measurements.  Finally, we studied the mechanisms by which light-emitting molecules are quenched in biological systems through nonadiabatic processes. Quenching methods are a foundational tool for many biological studies. We used the advanced laser spectroscopy methods developed in our laboratory to discern the mechanism that is active in fluorogenic bioconjugation reactions involving tetrazines.  The results will inform design principles for other well-known tetrazine-based systems, which could increase the brightness or contrast for biological imaging studies.
